page.title: 14Women's Cricket in Colwall
page.content: Colwall is the birthplace of the {Women's Cricket Association}and every August some 140 of England's best women cricketers merge on the village for a unique week-long competition, playing matches on the grounds of local schools and clubs. It all began in 1936 when Mrs Scott-Bowden, a member of the women's Hereford West cricket team, proposed a women's cricket match in the village. Later that year the Women's Cricket Association was set up at a meeting in London. It was decided that players from the various clubs in the country should meet in one place, Colwall, and that the players should be put up at private houses in the village. Thus began the Cricket Week, and each year a committee picks 12 equal teams for a tournament in which each team plays all the others.
